Title:
Morphological and molecular characterization of Fusarium
pseudograminearum sp. nov., formerly recognized as the group 1
population of F. graminearum.
Keywords:
ß-tubulin; crown rot; DNA sequence; head scab; morphology;
mycotoxigenic; systematics; translation elongation factor
Abstract:
Fusarium pseudograminearum sp. nov., formally known as F.
graminearum group 1, is described and illustrated. Fusarium
pseudograminearum can be distinguished from F. graminearum based on
difference in colony growth rates, region of conidia with greatest
width, different reactions to black-light-blue light concerning the
length of 3- and 5-septate conidia, and absence of homothallic
production of perithecia. Maximum parsimony analysis of DNA sequences
from the beta-tubulin gene introns and exons indicate that F.
pseudograminearum represents a phylogenetically distinct species that is
a sister group to a F. graminearum-F. lunulosporum-F. culmorum clade.
DNA sequence data from the translation elongation factor (EF-1 alpha)
gene were used to develop a polymerase chain reaction primer pair which
specifically amplified DNA from all isolates of Fusarium
pseudograminearum tested.
